item.title: Explosions Reported in Venezuela’s Capital
item.description: It was not immediately clear what caused the blasts. The United States has been building pressure on Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s authoritarian president, for months.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Matias Delacroix/Associated Press
item.media:description: Smoke rising near La Carlota airport after explosions and low-flying aircraft were heard in Caracas, Venezuela, on Saturday.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Pamela Colman Smith, Artist Behind a Famous Tarot Deck
item.description: She hand-painted around 80 illustrations for the Rider-Waite deck, which is still used around the world to predict destinies.
item.dc:creator: Emily Palmer

item.title: Coast Guard Suspends Search for Survivors of Latest Boat Strikes
item.description: The service said that conditions in the area where the search was taking place included nine-foot seas and winds approaching 50 miles per hour.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Coast Guard ship at Coast Guard Base San Juan on Wednesday. The strike on Tuesday was the fourth known instance of people surviving, at least initially, one of the 35 military strikes against boats in the Caribbean Sea and the eastern Pacific.

item.title: Oil Tanker Fleeing U.S. Coast Guard Broadcasts Location in North Atlantic
item.description: Russia requested this week that the United States end its pursuit of the vessel, which was intercepted in the Caribbean on its way to pick up oil in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Nicholas Nehamas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Håkon Rimmereid
item.media:description: The oil tanker Bella 1, photographed in March. It recently appeared in Russia’s official register of ships under a new name, the Marinera.

item.title: Search Is Suspended for Passenger Who Went Overboard From Cruise Ship
item.description: The U.S. Coast Guard said on Thursday that it halted its hourslong search for a 77-year-old woman who went overboard from a Holland America Line cruise ship near Cuba.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Finnbarr Webster/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Holland America Line cruise ship Nieuw Statendam in Portland, in southwest England, in 2024. A 77-year-old woman went overboard from the ship as it was cruising near Cuba on Thursday.

item.title: Venezuela Frees Dozens of Political Prisoners
item.description: At least 80 people were released, including one with U.S. ties, though more than 800 remain detained in Venezuela for opposing President Nicolás Maduro’s rule, rights groups say.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of women holding handkerchiefs with the names of political prisoners in Caracas in November.

item.title: Russia Asks United States to Stop Pursuit of Fleeing Oil Tanker
item.description: The tanker, which had been sailing to Venezuela to pick up oil, has claimed Russian protection, although the U.S. authorities say it is a stateless vessel.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Edward Wong and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui/Reuters
item.media:description: A U.S. Coast Guard helicopter flying in Puerto Rico last month.

item.title: Coast Guard Searches for Survivors After More Boat Strikes
item.description: The U.S. military attacked a convoy of three boats in the eastern Pacific on Tuesday, and two more on Wednesday, as part of the Trump administration’s campaign against people suspected of drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Coast Guard cutter in San Juan, P.R. An undetermined number of people survived strikes by the U.S. military on boats in the Pacific Ocean on Tuesday.

item.title: Venezuela Detains U.S. Citizens Amid Trump Administration’s Growing Pressure
item.description: The number of American citizens held in Venezuela has grown since the start of the U.S. military and economic campaign against President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Annie Correal and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela at a rally in Caracas, the capital, earlier this month.

item.title: New Year’s 2026 Celebrations Around the World: Photos and Videos
item.description: See how people across the globe celebrated.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times

item.title: He Is Being Sued in the U.S. for Human Rights Abuses. He Could be Deported First.
item.description: Rafael Quero Silva faces a lawsuit brought by five people who say he oversaw their abuse and mistreatment as a military officer in Venezuela. But he could be deported before the case is heard.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Even as Trump Targets Boats in Strikes, Coast Guard Continues Anti-Drug Operations
item.description: Cutters are still stopping smugglers and seizing drugs, but the prosecutions of go-fast boat crews are dwindling in a realignment of federal resources.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: For the most part, people captured by the Coast Guard on the same smuggling routes the U.S. military is bombing are being repatriated.

item.title: The C.I.A. Strike on Venezuela: What to Know
item.description: The drone attack, said to be on a dock where drugs were being prepared for loading on boats, represented a further escalation of the Trump administration’s campaign against Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui/Reuters
item.media:description: An American MQ-9 Reaper drone at an airfield in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico, last week. The C.I.A. used a drone to target a suspected drug-trafficking site in Venezuela.

item.title: Crew Paints Russian Flag on Oil Tanker Pursued by the U.S. Coast Guard
item.description: The U.S. military tried to intercept the Bella 1 last week in the Caribbean Sea as it headed to Venezuela to pick up oil.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Nicholas Nehamas and Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: C.I.A. Conducted Drone Strike on Port in Venezuela
item.description: The attack last week, on a dock purportedly used for shipping narcotics, did not kill anyone, people briefed on the operation said. But it was the first known U.S. operation inside Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaking to reporters on Monday, President Trump had declined to say how the attack had been carried out or by whom but confirmed the United States was responsible.

item.title: U.S. Kills 2 in Strike in Pacific, as Trump Pressures Venezuela
item.description: The attack was the 30th announced by the U.S. military since early September. It came days after President Trump said the U.S. had struck a coastal site related to drugs and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The strike, conducted at the direction of Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, had targeted a boat sailing along a “known narco-trafficking route” in the eastern Pacific.

item.title: Grim Evidence of Trump’s Boat Strikes Washes Ashore on a Colombian Peninsula
item.description: First came the scorched boat. Then the mangled bodies. Then the packets with traces of marijuana. Now, fishermen fear the ocean that feeds them.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Simón Posada, Christiaan Triebert and Federico Rios
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Claire Brosseau Wants to Die. Will Canada Let Her?
item.description: Ms. Brosseau says mental illness has made her life unbearable. She wants a medically assisted death. Even her psychiatrists are split over whether she should have one.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Chloë Ellingson
item.media:credit: Chloë Ellingson for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Says the U.S. Struck a ‘Big Facility’ in Campaign Against Venezuela
item.description: The administration provided no details of what the president said was an attack last week linked to U.S. efforts to disrupt drug trafficking from Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Such an attack would be the first on land since President Trump began his military campaign against Venezuela.

item.title: Mexico Train Derailment Kills 13 People
item.description: The train was carrying around 250 passengers and crew members on a cross-country route linking the Pacific and the Gulf of Mexico. Nearly 100 people were injured.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Rusvel Rasgado/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mexican emergency workers rescuing passengers from a train that derailed in the southern state of Oaxaca on Sunday.

item.title: Twins’ Peaks: The Gilbertson Brothers Want to Rewrite Your Country’s Map
item.description: Two brothers, both mechanical engineers, are climbing many of the world’s tall peaks to prove they have been measured incorrectly.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Scoles

item.title: What to Know About Colombia’s Role in the Global Drug Trade Amid Trump’s Feud With Petro
item.description: President Gustavo Petro is locked in a war of words with President Trump over Colombia’s major role in the global drug trade. The issue is complicated.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Ramón Campos Iriarte for The New York Times

item.title: How Oil, Drugs and Immigration Fueled Trump’s Venezuela Campaign
item.description: New details of deliberations show how aides with overlapping agendas drove the United States toward a militarized confrontation with Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager, Charlie Savage, Julian E. Barnes and Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, left, and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, right, have been key players, alongside the presidential adviser Stephen Miller, in President Trump’s escalating conflict in Venezuela.

item.title: A Sweeping Look at One Thing That Unites Canada: Winter
item.description: The National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa has a major exhibition of 164 works from around the world depicting winter and the place of people and animals within it.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jean-François Bélisle with “Winter Woodland” by Lawren S. Harris.

item.title: A Dancing Dictator and Bankers in Chains: The Other Venezuela Blockade
item.description: A crisis more than a century ago involved U.S. aims to assert military supremacy, a hard-partying dictator and frictions among the great powers.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Library of Congress
item.media:description: Cipriano Castro, who ruled Venezuela from 1899 to 1908. Known as the “Lion of the Andes,” he defied the great powers of the era.
